slides.title: Welcome to Logic and Set Theory
slides.content:
# Introduction to Logic and Set Theory

Welcome to **Logic and Set Theory** - the foundations of mathematics!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Propositions** - True/false statements
- **Logical Connectives** - AND, OR, NOT
- **Sets** - Collections of objects
- **Set Operations** - Union, intersection
- **Proofs** - Mathematical reasoning

> **Fun Fact:** Georg Cantor proved there are different sizes of infinity!

slides.title: Propositions
slides.content:
# Propositions

## Definition:
A statement that is either true or false.

## Examples:
- "2 + 2 = 4" (TRUE)
- "Paris is in Germany" (FALSE)
- "5 > 3" (TRUE)

## Non-Propositions:
- "What time is it?" (question)
- "Close the door." (command)
- "x + 1 = 5" (depends on x)

## Notation:
- p, q, r for propositions
- T or 1 for true
- F or 0 for false

slides.title: Logical Connectives
slides.content:
# Logical Connectives

## Main Connectives:

| Connective | Symbol | Meaning |
|------------|--------|--------|
| NOT | ~ or not | Negation |
| AND | /\ or & | Conjunction |
| OR | \/ or | | Disjunction |
| IF...THEN | -> | Implication |
| IF AND ONLY IF | <-> | Biconditional |

## Truth Tables:

**NOT p:**
| p | ~p |
|---|----|
| T | F |
| F | T |

**p AND q:**
True only when BOTH are true.

slides.title: Truth Tables
slides.content:
# Truth Tables

## p OR q:
| p | q | p OR q |
|---|---|--------|
| T | T | T |
| T | F | T |
| F | T | T |
| F | F | F |

## p -> q (Implication):
| p | q | p -> q |
|---|---|--------|
| T | T | T |
| T | F | F |
| F | T | T |
| F | F | T |

## Key Insight:
Implication is false ONLY when:
- Hypothesis is true
- Conclusion is false

slides.title: Logical Equivalences
slides.content:
# Logical Equivalences

## Important Laws:

**De Morgan's Laws:**
```
~(p AND q) = (~p) OR (~q)
~(p OR q) = (~p) AND (~q)
```

**Double Negation:**
```
~~p = p
```

**Contrapositive:**
```
(p -> q) = (~q -> ~p)
```

**Distributive:**
```
p AND (q OR r) = (p AND q) OR (p AND r)
```

slides.title: Quantifiers
slides.content:
# Quantifiers

## Universal Quantifier:
"For all" - denoted by forall symbol
```
For all x, P(x)
```
True if P(x) is true for EVERY x.

## Existential Quantifier:
"There exists" - denoted by exists symbol
```
There exists x such that P(x)
```
True if P(x) is true for AT LEAST ONE x.

## Negation:
```
~(For all x, P(x)) = There exists x, ~P(x)
~(There exists x, P(x)) = For all x, ~P(x)
```

slides.title: Introduction to Sets
slides.content:
# Sets

## Definition:
A collection of distinct objects.

## Notation:
- A = {1, 2, 3}
- B = {x | x is even}
- Empty set: {} or null set symbol

## Membership:
- 2 in A (2 is a member of A)
- 5 not in A

## Important Sets:
| Symbol | Set |
|--------|-----|
| N | Natural numbers {0, 1, 2, ...} |
| Z | Integers |
| Q | Rationals |
| R | Real numbers |

slides.title: Set Operations
Subsets and Cardinality
slides.content:
# Subsets and Cardinality

## Subset:
A subset of B means every element of A is in B.

## Proper Subset:
A is proper subset of B means A subset of B and A != B.

## Cardinality:
Number of elements in a set.
|A| = cardinality of A

## Examples:
- {1, 2} subset of {1, 2, 3}
- |{a, b, c}| = 3
- |empty set| = 0

## Power Set:
Set of all subsets.
|P(A)| = 2^|A|

slides.title: Venn Diagrams
slides.content:
# Venn Diagrams

## Purpose:
Visualize set relationships.

## Two Sets:
- Two overlapping circles
- Intersection in overlap
- A - B in A only
- B - A in B only

## Three Sets:
- Three overlapping circles
- 8 possible regions

## Uses:
- Solving counting problems
- Visualizing logic
- Set operation verification

## Inclusion-Exclusion:
|A union B| = |A| + |B| - |A intersect B|

slides.title: Proof Techniques
slides.content:
# Proof Techniques

## Direct Proof:
1. Assume hypothesis
2. Use definitions and theorems
3. Arrive at conclusion

## Proof by Contradiction:
1. Assume statement is FALSE
2. Derive a contradiction
3. Therefore statement is TRUE

## Proof by Contrapositive:
Prove ~q -> ~p instead of p -> q

## Mathematical Induction:
1. Base case: Prove for n = 1
2. Inductive step: If true for n, prove for n + 1
3. Conclusion: True for all n

slides.title: Mathematical Induction
slides.content:
# Mathematical Induction

## Structure:
**Base Case:** Verify for n = 1 (or first value).

**Inductive Hypothesis:** Assume true for n = k.

**Inductive Step:** Prove true for n = k + 1.

**Conclusion:** True for all n >= 1.

## Example:
Prove 1 + 2 + ... + n = n(n+1)/2

**Base:** n = 1: 1 = 1(2)/2 = 1. TRUE.

**Step:** Assume true for k.
1 + 2 + ... + k + (k+1)
= k(k+1)/2 + (k+1)
= (k+1)(k+2)/2. TRUE.

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Logic and Set Theory Summary

## Logic:
- Propositions: True or false
- Connectives: AND, OR, NOT, IF-THEN
- De Morgan's Laws

## Sets:
| Operation | Result |
|-----------|--------|
| Union | All in either |
| Intersection | All in both |
| Difference | In A but not B |

## Proofs:
- Direct
- Contradiction
- Induction

## Foundation:
Logic and sets underpin all mathematics.

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Logic and Set Theory!
